awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Development of 3D Second Harmonic Generation Tomography and Deep Learning Algorithms for Classification of Human Ovarian Cancer
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal will address the problem of distinguishing between normal tissue and precancer tissue changes, critical for successful treatment of ovarian cancer. Ovarian cancer has a very poor prognosis unless detected at the earliest stage, which is extremely difficult. Current clinical imaging techniques lack sufficient resolution, specificity, and sensitivity for effective differentiation of normal and diseased cancerous tissue. 


There is a pressing need for new insight into disease etiology and progression. The PI will develop new Second Harmonic Generation (SHG) imaging tools for this purpose. They will extend current SHG microscopy to tomography for better characterization of 3D collagen structure. They will a) develop SHG excitation tomography; b) develope new reconstruction algorithms; and c) incorporate the 3D data into a respective classification scheme, and explore the use of deep learning algorithms to refine the classification analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project was directed at developing new 3D approaches to determine how changes in the extracellular matrix are involved in disease initiation and progression in ovarian cancer.  We previously showed evidence of these changes in a spectrum of ovarian cancers, but we sought to develop a more complete and rigorous physical description. Our primary tool has been Second Harmonic Generation (SHG) microscopy, which selectively images collagen, which is the primary component of this matrix. Moreover, due to the underlying physical attributes, this modality can be exploited to determine several structural biology aspects including fibril architecture as well as supramolecular attributes of the collagen triple helix.  We developed a new instrument to develop SHG microscopy into a true tomographic method, akin to computed tomography (CT), but on much smaller size scales. The significant challenge lies in the 3D reconstruction, as the underlying physics preclude using standard reconstruction techniques used in CT and other clinical modalities but can also be exploited to best represent the collagen structure. We have now developed a rigorous approach to this problem, that can be applied to ovarian cancer and many other diseased states as well.  We have also developed a new theoretical framework to ascertain features that are below the resolution of SHG optical microscopy. Specifically, we have developed a method based on quasi-phasematching to determine the average size and spacing of collagen fibrils, which are on the order of 100-200 nm in diameter. Historically, this level of analysis has required the use of electron microscopy, which requires significant sample preparation and is inherently low throughput. This is important as there are structural changes in the fibril assembly in many diseased states including cancers and fibroses as well as connective tissue disorders. Lastly, we developed a new image generation framework using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs). This approach allows us to not only classify tissues classes by machine learning, but also allows us to extract out the characteristic collagen features that best represent different classes of tissues, e.g. normal vs diseased. This is a new approach to using GANs for analysis of microscope-based data. Collectively, the suite of tools we developed in this project are applicable for the study of numerous diseases that are characterized by changes in the collagen architecture.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/19/2023
Modified by: Paul J Campagnola
